name: concrete block production | concrete block | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21100/documentation

This dataset describes the production of concrete blocks in Brazil. The blocks have a characteristic compressive strength of 4 MPa and are used in non-structural masonry walls and in structural masonry of houses and low-rise buildings. The manufacturing process begins by dosing and mixing the cement, aggregates and water to make concrete. The concrete is transported to the block machine by conveyor belts. In the block machine, the steel cast is filled with concrete and the block is shaped and compacted by vibration. The fresh concrete block is then transported to the curing chambers. The cure can be done in the following ways: 1) naturally, leaving the blocks in closed chambers with no water addition; 2) wet cure, spraying water over the blocks to keep relative humidity high in order to ensure proper hydration of the cement; 3) thermal cure with steam, which enables the cement to hydrate faster than in the wet cure and lowers concrete shrinkage. The blocks are then packed in pallets and stored. The process can happen with various automation levels and different types and sizes of block machines. It is common to produce various block shapes and compressive strength classes in a single factory, as well as concrete pavers.;Concrete dry mass considers the amount of water that reacts with cement to form hydrates. As a consequence, this dataset is not water balanced according to ecoinvent guidelines.;The dataset includes the whole manufacturing process of the concrete block. It does not include administration and infrastructure.;Data collection was performed by the Polytechnic School of the University of São Paulo (EPUSP), the Brazilian Council for Sustainable Construction (CBCS), the Brazilian Association of the Concrete Block Industry (BlocoBrasil) and the Brazilian Association of Portland Cement (ABCP) covering the years of 2012 and 2013 (CBCS, ABCP, BLOCO BRASIL, no date).;This dataset contains data of 25 factories located in 6 different states in the southern and southeastern regions of Brazil, which cover different factory sizes and technologies, thus being representative of the current Brazilian technological mix for concrete block production. The representativeness of the dataset on a national scale is considered good (ca. 50% of the Brazilian concrete block production).;CBCS, ABCP, BLOCOBRASIL. Projeto Avaliação de Ciclo de Vida Modular de Blocos e Pisos de Concreto. Available at: <http://www.blocobrasil.com.br/projetos/cbcs-ciclo-de-vida-modular> . Accessed on 14.09.2017.

From the reception of raw materials in the concrete block factory.

This activity ends at the concrete block factory gate. The dataset includes dosing and mixing of concrete, concrete block production by vibration, curing, packing and storage, as well as internal transports. Infrastructure, administration and factory maintenance are not considered due to lack of data.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2395:Manufacture of articles of concrete, cement and plaster

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is set to the years 2012-2013 as this was the period of data collection.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents production of concrete blocks representative for Brazil. Data come from primary data collection in Brazil.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The dataset covers the main technologies for concrete block production in Brazil.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data from approximately 50% of the Brazilian production volume are representing the national concrete block production.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Data gathered in 25 concrete block factories located in 6 states in the southern and southeastern regions of Brazil, with good representativeness on a national scale. Data cover different production technologies in terms of automation, factory size and curing options, which explains the variation observed in the unit flows; however, splitting the data into different technologies was not possible, as the companies were not identified nor their production process characterized due to confidentiality issues. Data were collected via questionnaires applied during the project “Modular LCA of concrete blocks”, carried out by EPUSP, CBCS, BLOCOBRASIL and ABCP during the years of 2012 and 2013. Data represent 01 year of operation for each plant. 
Unit flows were calculated as a weighted average between the factories, considering their total production volumes (all types of blocks and pavers) in mass. The flows regarding concrete composition of the 4 MPa block were calculated considering the cement content declared by the manufacturers and using mathematical relations for calculating aggregate consumption (described in the exchange comments). The flows regarding electricity, fuel and water consumption, as well as waste generation were calculated by dividing their consumption by the total production of the factory in mass, which means an implicit mass allocation for these items. However, declaring all multiple outputs of different concrete blocks and pavers was not possible due to lack of data - only the total production volumes of the factories were informed. Water evaporation was modelled considering a previous data collection in one concrete block factory (further explanation in the exchange comment field). To account for emissions to air from combustion for steam production for curing, existing ecoinvent heat production processes were used, but as they are not specific to the boilers and other industrial equipment used in the concrete block factory, it is considered a proxy.
Basic uncertainty was calculated based on sample variation. Additional uncertainty was estimated using Pedigree scores.
The amount of the exchanges were calculated considering the weighted average of the sample. No conversion to the geometric mean of the lognormal distribution was done, for consistency reasons with other ecoinvent datasets.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=DE
The dataset represents 1 kg of a 4 MPa hollow concrete block, with dimensions (140 x 390 x 190) mm (width x length x height) and average mass of 12,4 kg, meeting the requirements of the Brazilian technical standard ABNT NBR 6136.

flow.name: concrete block
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2395:Manufacture of articles of concrete, cement and plaster

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Total of water output x fraction of water released to air. See further comments in the parameters field.

Measured value. Weighted average of amounts informed by the block factories. For those that do not use this fuel source, the value was set to zero. Losses already considered. Diesel can be used for internal transport equipment and in boilers to generate steam for curing. 

EcoSpold01Location=GLO

flow.name: diesel, burned in building machine
flow.category: F:Construction/43:Specialized construction activities/431:Demolition and site preparation/4312:Site preparation

defaultProvider.name: market for diesel, burned in building machine | diesel, burned in building machine | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: F:Construction/43:Specialized construction activities/431:Demolition and site preparation/4312:Site preparation

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Aggregate mass is the concrete block mass (1kg) minus the water mass, the cement mass and the combined water mass (water that reacted with cement). Only the total consumption of aggregates for the factory was informed, not the exact mix for the concrete block. Thus, it was assumed that the share of the specific aggregate (sand or gravel) is equal regardless of block type, which is a proxy. Gravel includes crushed gravel of different sizes and artificial sand. Losses considered.

flow.name: gravel, crushed
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/081:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay/0810:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay

defaultProvider.name: market for gravel, crushed | gravel, crushed | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/081:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay/0810:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay

exchanges.description: Measured value. Weighted average of amounts (consumption of liquefied petroleum gas in L) informed by the block factories. For those that do not use this fuel source, the value was set to zero. Losses already considered. LPG can be used for internal transport equipment and in boilers to generate steam for curing. Propane is used as a proxy. Density of liquefied petroleum gas: 0,552 kg/L (Brazilian National Energy Balance 2016).

exchanges.description: Measured value. Weighted average of amounts (consumption of natural gas in L) informed by the block factories. For those that do not use this fuel source, the value was set to zero. Losses already considered. Natural gas can be used in boilers to generate steam for curing. Density of natural gas = 0,74 kg/m³ (Brazilian National Energy Balance 2016).
